subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I'd like to
talk a little bit today about macro
psycokinesis. It's a topic I keep
referring back to over and over again.
It's probably among the most
controversial things in the whole field
of parapsychology. Of course,
observations of macro psychokinetic
events go back at least to the 19th
century, the era of spiritualism
and seances. Many, many different
phenomena were reported in the seances:
table levitations, rappings, knocks,
materializations, apports, unusual voices,
ectoplasm appearing, spirit forms
appearing, spirit photographs. At the
same time, the magicians - and I don't
mean real magicians -
I mean stage magicians learned how to
simulate these effects and some of them
made a living pretending to be
spiritualist mediums but using magic
tricks the whole time. So, the field has
been intertwined with fraud going back
now 150 years or so. Nevertheless,
many credible researchers under rather
well controlled conditions reported
unusual psychokinetic effects, including
people like Alfred Russel Wallace, the
co-inventor of the theory of evolution,
or should I say co-discoverer of the
theory of evolution with Charles Darwin.
Now, research into table levitation also
occurred in the 1960s and 1970s. In
England a man named Kenneth Batcheldor
began working with a group of people to
try and simulate some of the events that
were reported in the previous century.
He got people together but he wasn't
interested in the
spiritual or religious context of a
seance. He didn't have anybody going into
trance. He didn't have any spirit mediums
in the room. But, he got a group of people
together to sit around a table and see
if they could make the table levitate.
He worked very hard to develop a
table that could be measured
scientifically, so he had switches on all
the feet of the table so that if the
table raised up from the ground the
switches would trigger and it would
create a recording. He put buzzers on the
table, he put luminous strips of paper so
if the table were to lift up in a
dark room with just the tiniest amount of
light the luminous strips on the table
could be seen and photographed. He
reported success in numerous experiments
doing this sort of thing completely
separate from the spiritualistic context.
It was based on the work of
Batcheldor in England that members of the
Toronto Society for Psychical Research
in Canada decided to try and emulate the
Batcheldor approach with a little twist.
Now, one of the things I will say about
Batcheldor's work is that the seances
that he held - and they weren't real
seances as I point out - the sessions that
he held ran for about two hours with a
half hour break. Typically, what he
reported is nothing happened at all for
at least 10 minutes. So, people had to be
willing to be patient and to develop
a kind of playful attitude. Batcheldor
also noticed that people who believe
that this was possible - once again
the sheep-goat effect that I've talked
about earlier - the belief system of
the participants was crucial to getting
the phenomena to occur. Once a table
started lifting, even one leg started
lifting and people's hands were on top of
the table
trying to hold it down, in effect, and its
lifting in spite of that. When that
happens, that creates instantaneously a
sense of awe amongst the people in the
room, like "Wow, it's starting to happen."
That emotion seems to be conducive
to even more phenomena. So, once it gets
started it tends to increase and you can
get a lot of rapping and levitation
going. Now, in Toronto what they decided
to do - this is really clever -
they created a fictional story, like a
Gothic novel about a ghost named Philip
who has lost his love and was pining for
her. They created this story and they
all treated the story as if it were true.
They decided to see if they couldn
get a rapping, knocks - one rap for yes,
two for no - and answers to their questions
and could they conjure up a ghost who
never existed, who is simply a fictional
creation. They did. They found that
they could hold sessions - now again, we
call them seances but they didn't have
the solemnity of some of the
spiritualist seances. People were not
praying, people were not endeavoring
to contact their departed loved ones. In
fact, what they tried to do in Toronto
is very interesting. They tried to
recreate what they called sort of
the boisterous, jolly side of
19th century Spiritualism where
they'd get together, they'd sing songs,
they would tell jokes, they would talk
about getting drunk. That seemed to
be conducive to what they call -
the title of the book in fact,
Conjuring up Philip - this imaginary ghost
who when they asked questions that
they hadn't developed a clear answer to
in their fictional account of Philip, the
raps would often be very soft
and
indistinct. But when the questions were
asked about things that were very
definite, already part of the fictional
creation, then the raps would be louder
and clearer. Now,
the intriguing thing is that it's
unlikely that there was a real ghost, a
real spirit trying to simulate the
fictional creation of Philip, it's more
likely I think that the raps that were
produced, the table levitations that were
produced were the result of
psychokinesis from the participants in
the room. We can't say for sure, we can't
absolutely rule out the spiritualist
hypothesis, but it calls it into question.
It suggests that even in the 19th
century seances, even the ectoplasmic
materializations, perhaps those weren't
real spiritualistic phenomena, perhaps
those were psychokinetic productions. We
don't know at this point. I have to say
some people are disposed to lean towards
a spiritualist interpretation
and others are not, but there's no clear cut
answer as of yet. Either possibility, I
think, is very exciting. It's very
exciting to think about humans finding
ways to cultivate mind over matter,
psychokinetic talents. It's also very
exciting to think that it's possible for
humans to communicate with spirits, even
imaginary spirits. The creation of Philip
is not so different from the accounts
and the writing of Alexandra David-
Neel about the Tibetan tulpa who is
created the same way, a fictional story
is conjured up about an individual.
In her account the person who is being
conjured up actually took on a physical
appearance, an apparition that was so
tangible that it seemed like a real
human being
traveling with Alexandra David-Neel and
her party of Tibetans. Well, what does
this mean for you? These are studies, the
most recent of which goes back
to the 1970s, it's not as if there's been
an ongoing continuation of the Philip
group. But, I will say this. There
was some research done by Dr. Joel
Whitten, as I recall, who did acoustical
measurements of the rapping sounds in
the table. Normally, if you
rap your finger, your knuckle on wood,
what you'll get is an acoustical
measurement: it starts sharply but it
kind of trails off a little bit. However,
with these paranormal raps, the
acoustical signature was different. It
starts abruptly and it ends abruptly. It
doesn't trail off the way it would if
you hit the table in order to create a
rapping sound. That does suggest a
completely different origin for those
raps. It certainly lends credence to the
idea of either the spiritualistic or the
psychokinetic hypothesis. In fact,
even the spiritualistic hypothesis seems
to imply psychokinesis perhaps from a
departed, not from a living entity,
but from a disembodied entity, you're
still talking about psychokinesis. Once
again though, I have to come back to the
question: what's in it for you? Are you
interested in table levitation
and creating rapping sounds? You know what, I
doubt it.
Very few of you out there are probably
interested in replicating that sort of a
phenomena. But knowing it exists,
what are the implications? If a group
of not professional mediums, not
professional psychics but interested
people, members of the Toronto Society
for Psychical Research can get together
in a group and by creating a fun filled
boisterous atmosphere
create legitimate psychokinetic
phenomena, what does that say about you?
What does it say about your
possibilities? What could you manifest if
you so desired? I'll leave you with that
thought. Thank you once again so much for
being with me.
